content.raw:
A couple of style details:

* the input parameter should be prefixed by `_`
* variables should be `camelCased`, i.e. `collisionShape`
content.html:
A couple of style details:

  • the input parameter should be prefixed by _
  • variables should be camelCased, i.e. collisionShape

content.raw: This is only being included for windows, was that the intention?
content.html: This is only being included for windows, was that the intention?

content.raw: Mind moving this include up together with the other `gazebo/common` one? It's easier to spot later :wink:
content.html: Mind moving this include up together with the other gazebo/common one? It's easier to spot later

content.raw: It would be nice to rename this to `vis`, so it isn't confused with an input parameter, because those have the `_` prefix.
content.html: It would be nice to rename this to vis, so it isn't confused with an input parameter, because those have the _ prefix.

content.raw:
I think it doesn't affect the result, but maybe this should be `GetElement("collision")` for consistency?

Another idea would be to start from an empty element and construct it from there, since you're rebuilding the whole element for cylinders and spheres anyway. Just a suggestion :wink:
content.html:
I think it doesn't affect the result, but maybe this should be GetElement("collision") for consistency?

Another idea would be to start from an empty element and construct it from there, since you're rebuilding the whole element for cylinders and spheres anyway. Just a suggestion

content.raw: Ah nevermind, this is to create the "collision visual", so I guess we can reuse the "materials".
content.html: Ah nevermind, this is to create the "collision visual", so I guess we can reuse the "materials".

content.raw: What happens if there is no visual? I think the code below will crash. You could add a check here and create a box in that case.
content.html: What happens if there is no visual? I think the code below will crash. You could add a check here and create a box in that case.

content.raw:
This logic is repeated below for meshes. What do you think of moving this to a function? Something like:

`void BoxToCylinder(const ignition::math::Box &_box, double &_radius, double &_length, ignition::math::Quaternion &_rot)`

Where `_radius`, `_length` and `_rot` are output params.

In the future, it may be useful to move this to Ignition Math and use the new [ignition::math::Cylinder](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/src/7c83076419cf11404e5bfa2b5683b4a08c863918/include/ignition/math/Cylinder.hh?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) class.
content.html:
This logic is repeated below for meshes. What do you think of moving this to a function? Something like:

void BoxToCylinder(const ignition::math::Box &_box, double &_radius, double &_length, ignition::math::Quaternion &_rot)

Where _radius, _length and _rot are output params.

In the future, it may be useful to move this to Ignition Math and use the new ignition::math::Cylinder class.

You could do something like this to reduce repetition, which reduces the chance of some error in the middle:

         auto geomElem = collisionElem->GetElement("geometry");
         geomElem->ClearElements();

         auto cylinderElem = geomElem->AddElement("cylinder");
         cylinderElem->AddElement("radius")->Set(radius);
         cylinderElem->AddElement("length")->Set(length);

The same idea can be used to other parts of the code.

content.raw: Do we really want to create a mesh in case it doesn't exist? I think that in this use case, the mesh should be already loaded, right?
content.html: Do we really want to create a mesh in case it doesn't exist? I think that in this use case, the mesh should be already loaded, right?

content.raw: Better not to create this as a pointer, otherwise we need to delete it after using it.
content.html: Better not to create this as a pointer, otherwise we need to delete it after using it.

content.raw: Suggestion: Use `size.X()/Y()/Z()` instead of `[0]/[1]/[2]` - personally I find that easier to follow when reading the code
content.html: Suggestion: Use size.X()/Y()/Z() instead of [0]/[1]/[2] - personally I find that easier to follow when reading the code

content.raw:
I found a situation in which I think the logic could be improved. Try for example with a visual sized:

* x == 2.0
* y == 3.0
* z == 1.0

Looking at the box, it feels that the cylinder should be oriented along the Y axis, but it ends up around Z:

![cylz.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4227610181-cylz.png)
 
I think this happens because the difference is the same between X/Y and X/Z. How about, in this case, adding an extra check to orient the cylinder along the longest side (Y > Z)?
content.html:
I found a situation in which I think the logic could be improved. Try for example with a visual sized:

  • x == 2.0
  • y == 3.0
  • z == 1.0

Looking at the box, it feels that the cylinder should be oriented along the Y axis, but it ends up around Z:

I think this happens because the difference is the same between X/Y and X/Z. How about, in this case, adding an extra check to orient the cylinder along the longest side (Y > Z)?

content.html: Looking good! I left a few preliminary comments, but in general everything works for me. We can start thinking about tests once these first comments are addressed
